Ripley, S.D. 1977. Rails of the world. M.F. Feheley Publishers, Ltd., Toronto. 406 pp.
Hands, H.M., R.D. Drobney, and M.R. Ryan. 1989. Status of the black rail in the northcentral United States. Missouri Coop. Fish Wildl. Res. Unit Rep. 11 pp.
Carter, M., G. Fenwick, C. Hunter, D. Pashley, D. Petit, J. Price, and J. Trapp. 1996. Watchlist 1996:For the future. Field Notes 50(3):238-240.
Andrle, R. F. and J. R. Carroll, Eds. 1987. The Atlas of Breeding Birds in New York state, Cornell Univ. Press, Ithaca, NY.
National Geographic Society (NGS). 1983. Field guide to the birds of North America. National Geographic Society, Washington, D.C.
Evens, J., and G. W. Page. 1986. Predation on black rails during high tides in salt marshes. Condor 88:107-109.
Thompson, M.C. et al. 2011. Birds of Kansas. University Press of Kansas, Lawrence.
Proctor, N. 1981. The black rail:mystery bird of the marsh. Connecticut Warbler 1(2):15-16.
Harrison, H.H. 1979. A field guide to western birds' nests. Houghton Mifflin Company, Boston. 279 pp.
American Ornithologists' Union (AOU). 1983. Check-list of North American Birds, 6th edition. Allen Press, Inc., Lawrence, Kansas. 877 pp.

Kerlinger, P., and D. S. Wiedner. 1990. Habitat use and vocal behavior of black rails in South Jersey. Unpublished draft report. New Jersey Department of Environmental Protection, Endangered and Nongame Species Program. 18 pp.
Raffaele, H.A. 1983. A guide to the birds of Puerto Rico and the Virgin Islands. Fondo Educativo Interamericano, San Juan, Puerto Rico. 255 pp.

Eddleman, W.R., R.E. Flores, and M.L. Legare. 1994. Black Rail (LATERALLUS JAMAICENSIS). In A. Poole and F. Gill, editors, The Birds of North America, No. 123. Academy of Natural Sciences, Philadelphia, and American Ornithologists Union, Washington, DC. 2
Terres, J.K. 1980. The Audubon Society encyclopedia of North American birds. Alfred A. Knopf, New York.
Bent, A. C. 1926. Life histories of North American marsh birds. U.S. National Museum Bulletin No. 135. [reprint. 1963. Dover Publications, Inc., New York, New York].

Davidson, L. M. 1992. Black rail, LATERALLUS JAMAICENSIS. Pages 119-134 in K. J. Schneider and D. M. Pence, editors. Migratory nongame birds of management concern in the Northeast. U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, Newton Corner, Massachusetts. 400 pp.
Griscom, L. 1923. Birds of the New York City region. American Museum of Natural History, Handbook Series No. 9, New York, New York. 400 pp.

Ehrlich, P.R., D.S. Dobkin, and D. Wheye. 1992. Birds in jeopardy:the imperiled and extinct birds of the United States and Canada, including Hawaii and Puerto Rico. Stanford University Press, Stanford, California. 259 pp.

Todd, R. L. 1977. Black rail, little black rail, black crake and farallon rail (LATERALLUS JAMAICENSIS). Pages 71-83 in G. C. Sanderson, editor. Management of migratory shore and upland game birds in North America. Int. Assoc. Fish and Wildl. Agencies, Wa
Stiles, F.G., and A.F. Skutch. 1989. A guide to the birds of Costa Rica. Comstock Publ. Associates, Cornell University Press, Ithaca, New York. 511 pp.
Harrison, C. 1978. A field guide to the nests, eggs and nestlings of North American birds. Collins, Cleveland, Ohio.

Armistead, H. T. 1990. Notes on black rails on the Delmarva Peninsula, especially in Dorchester County. Unpublished report. Maryland. Maryland Department of Natural Resources, Annapolis, Maryland. 6 pp.
